blog.title: remaking in progress
blog.description:
i dont know what sarcasm is. talk to my lifesize cardboard cut out of Shrek | Buy me a coffee! Check my links! | For mobile users: | FTM/nonbinary | Hawaiian | HOH. ASL | they/them and he/him only | (or check my About)
#antis dont interact. posts only.#

body:
Bakugou’s Nitroglycerin

So as a pharmacy student I know lots about nitroglycerin and how it works in the body and i thought itd be helpful for the writers in the BNHA fandom!

So, your body turns nitroglycerin into nitric oxide (a vasodilator) with ALDH2 so that it opens up your veins (all of them. As in the biggest secondary effect of nitroglycerin is headaches. Bad ones. Imagine all of your veins bECOMINg LIKE THIS suddenly, including the ones in your brain.)

And with the assumption that Bakugou lacks ALDH2, (it would turn into nitric oxide otherwisw) he could be lacking some vital things. ALDH2 is an enzyme and its part of the family that catalyze the chemical transformation of acetaldhyde ➡ acetic acid. ALDH2 is also the janitor for toxic products of free radicals. He would have (probably a lot) of acetaldhyde in his body.

So what the fuck does that mean? Well acetaldhyde is in things like coffee, bread, and is produced in lots of plants. It is produced by the partial oxidization of ethanol by an enzyme present when consuming alcohol. It basically causes most hangovers. So he likely doesnt experience many hangovers. But… people with a genetic deficiency for ALDH2 and cant convert the acetaldhyde to actic acid have a greater risk of Alzheimer’s. He also probably has some weird muscle growth as acetaldhyde causes abnormal muscle growth when it binds to proteins.

So Bakugou likely has a history of Alzheimer’s in his family but he could drink himself half to death and wake up pretty okay. He also is at super high risk for cancer as acetaldehyde is carcinogenic (the free radicals), and he deffo has some wicked ass (weird but cool probably) muscles.

summary: The Japanese honorific ‘chan’ is mostly used for females, and Nejire’s hero name is ‘Nejire-chan’. Soooo, trans-girl Nejire...
body: The Japanese honorific ‘chan’ is mostly used for females, and Nejire’s hero name is ‘Nejire-chan’. Soooo, trans-girl Nejire anyone?

blog.name: randomguywithwords
blog.title: Writing about random stuff.
blog.description: Hi, I'm a teenager guy who likes writing so this is mainly for writing-related stuff. I rarely reblog except to answer writing prompts. I welcome any criticism or comments.

title: Turncoat (Kaminari Traitor AU Short Story)
body:
“YOU PROMISED SHE WOULD BE SAFE!” Kaminari screamed over the pouring rain, shoving Dabi against the alley wall The fire-user didn’t seem fazed in the slightest with Kaminari’s hands pressing against his shoulders, with his usual unconcerned expression, hands in his pockets, which only fueled the blonde’s rage. 

“I tried, but even I can’t control Moonfish’s…tendencies. I told him to stay on that path, so that must have meant your girlfriend ran into him, not the other way around.” Dabi said nonchalantly. 

“You…you…bastard,” Kaminari choked. “What I did, my only condition was that she be left unharmed. You –”

“I told you not to get attached to anyone. That was a condition I specified. So it seems like you broke my condition first.”

“This is not my fault,” Kaminari seethed, blood pounding in his head.

“Isn’t it? If it was anyone else, you wouldn’t have given a damn. Now your girl’s gone and suddenly you’re turning against us? You’re disgusting.” Dabi snorted. 

Kaminari opened his mouth in a retort, but only silence followed. He closed it and released his grip. 

“I’m going to kill you, and everyone else,” Kaminari snarled. “I can promise that.”

“Why not now? It’s raining. My fire powers are basically useless. Go on, enact your vengeance, since your morals are clearly in place.” Dabi laughed. “You got nowhere to go, kid. You’ll be locked up the minute you tell everyone it was you who leaked the location of the camp and got a student killed. Ironically, you’d be double-crossing twice.”

Kaminari walked away in silence, leaving Dabi standing there with a smirk on his face. 

“Jiro? Jiro!” Kaminari stumbled through the bushes. He knew she was here somewhere. But where – 

Blood. 

The crimson liquid reflected in the pale moonlight, drawing his attention. He saw its source. 

“Oh god. Jiro!” He dashed to her side. Her clothes were torn and shredded. One of her earphone jacks was severed, the jack a few feet away. Her stomach was a pool of red. The red was dark. 

“No, no no no no no,” Kaminari whimpered. He put a trembling finger to her nose. 

“NO! JIRO! WAKE UP!” Rubbing his hands together, he concentrated two bursts of electricity at his fingertips and placed them on her chest. 

A heartbeat? 

No.

“Please, Jiro…” He sobbed. “Wake up…” Again, he tried. Again, nothing. 

Tears leaked down his face. 

“Jiro…Don’t go, don’t leave me,” Kaminari lightly shook her, praying for some miracle, that she would suddenly wake up and laugh at him for crying. He looked at her face, flecked with beads of blood.

Her face remained frozen, her eyes closed in one last look of acceptance. Peace, even.

And Kaminari was far from that.

“She…she told me to run and hide,” Hagakure was shaking with fits of crying, drawing breaths between sobs. The hospital bed was shuddering dangerously with her. 

“I saw her run back. She used her jacks to create a tremor. It drew its attention, and then…” Her words dissolved into tears

“You left her,” Kaminari stated coldly. Hagakure cried some more at that, but he didn’t care. “You. Left –” 

“Kaminari! That’s enough!” Yaoyoruzu silenced him. She too was struggling to hold back her tears. “It wasn’t her fault. She couldn’t have done anything.”

“YES SHE COULD!” Kaminari roared, causing those around him to take a step back. “A MILLION THINGS, AND SHE WOULD STILL BE HERE!”

“Kaminari,” Kirishima interrupted, putting a hand on him. “Outside.”

The blonde shook it off roughly and stalked towards the exit, hands in his jacket. 

“Everyone’s grieving, the same as you. Don’t take it out on Hagakure,” Kirishima said, with constrained calmness. 

Kaminari growled and pounded his hand against the wall. He started to cry again. “I just…I…”

“I know, man. We all know.”

No you don’t, Kaminari thought, as he sunk lower and lower to the floor. It’s all my fault.

The jail was quiet. In a cell was the imprisoned death row convict, his jaws fitted with titanium. Security cameras watched him, and two guards kept watch on the dangerous criminal. 

The guard watching the cameras, a block away, yawned. His shift was almost over. Just one more hour… 

Static. Inexplicably, the camera feed died, causing the guard to immediately pick up the phone “Detail 1, do you copy? My feed just went to static.” 

No response. His eyes widened. He picked up another phone. “Squadron 3, emergency situation in block 3. Requesting backup.”

In block 3, two guards lay on the ground, shuddering violently as their bodies received a sudden 50 volts. 

Moonfish stirred awake from his sleep at the sound of yells cut short, and the smell of ozone. “Who’s…there?”

“You don’t know me.” Kaminari approached him from the darkness till Moonfish could see the teenager. “But I do.”

“Child. You were…on the list. I know you…”  

“Good,” Kaminari snarled. “It makes killing you so much more satisfying.” He held up his hand, and a bolt of electricity formed between his fingertips. 

“No…please…” Moonfish raised his head, but Kaminari reacted faster, swerving to the side, dodging the blade that sprouted from his incisor, out of reach of the titanium bars. Thrusting his hand out, he grabbed the blade and channelled his electricity into it. 

Shrieks of pain emitted from the convict. His head fell limp. Kaminari ignored the blood from his cut. 

“A death row convict, huh?” Kaminari stepped closer to Moonfish, till he could smell the putrid stench of corpses and blood on the criminal’s suit. 

“Consider this your sentence carried out.” 

“Command, block 3 is cleared. Detail 1 is safe. Sending them for checkup.”

“And the prisoner?”

“The prisoner’s dead.”

“Dead? How?”

“Well, apart from its head, everything else is ash. Burning ash.”

“Bloody hell…”

“We might have a lead on the intruder. We’ve picked up traces of blood.”

“Good. Send it to us. We’re gonna catch this bastard.”

“…Sir?”

“Yes?”

“Don’t you think the prisoner deserved it? He killed a kid.”

“Damn right he deserved it. When we catch whoever murdered the prisoner, I’d send them my thanks before they end up in the slammer.”

“The prisoner’s dead.”

“Dead? How?”

“Well, apart from its head, everything else is ash. Burning ash.”

“Bloody hell…”

“We might have a lead on the intruder. We’ve picked up traces of blood.”

“Good. Send it to us. We’re gonna catch this bastard.”

“…Sir?”

“Yes?”

“Don’t you think the prisoner deserved it? He killed a kid.”

“Damn right he deserved it. When we catch whoever murdered the prisoner, I’d send them my thanks before they end up in the slammer.”
trail.content:
“YOU PROMISED SHE WOULD BE SAFE!” Kaminari screamed over the pouring rain, shoving Dabi against the alley wall The fire-user didn’t seem fazed in the slightest with Kaminari’s hands pressing against his shoulders, with his usual unconcerned expression, hands in his pockets, which only fueled the blonde’s rage. 

“I tried, but even I can’t control Moonfish’s…tendencies. I told him to stay on that path, so that must have meant your girlfriend ran into him, not the other way around.” Dabi said nonchalantly. 

“You…you…bastard,” Kaminari choked. “What I did, my only condition was that she be left unharmed. You –”

“I told you not to get attached to anyone. That was a condition I specified. So it seems like you broke my condition first.”

“This is not my fault,” Kaminari seethed, blood pounding in his head.

“Isn’t it? If it was anyone else, you wouldn’t have given a damn. Now your girl’s gone and suddenly you’re turning against us? You’re disgusting.” Dabi snorted. 

Kaminari opened his mouth in a retort, but only silence followed. He closed it and released his grip. 

“I’m going to kill you, and everyone else,” Kaminari snarled. “I can promise that.”

“Why not now? It’s raining. My fire powers are basically useless. Go on, enact your vengeance, since your morals are clearly in place.” Dabi laughed. “You got nowhere to go, kid. You’ll be locked up the minute you tell everyone it was you who leaked the location of the camp and got a student killed. Ironically, you’d be double-crossing twice.”

Kaminari walked away in silence, leaving Dabi standing there with a smirk on his face. 

“Jiro? Jiro!” Kaminari stumbled through the bushes. He knew she was here somewhere. But where – 

Blood. 

The crimson liquid reflected in the pale moonlight, drawing his attention. He saw its source. 

“Oh god. Jiro!” He dashed to her side. Her clothes were torn and shredded. One of her earphone jacks was severed, the jack a few feet away. Her stomach was a pool of red. The red was dark. 

“No, no no no no no,” Kaminari whimpered. He put a trembling finger to her nose. 

“NO! JIRO! WAKE UP!” Rubbing his hands together, he concentrated two bursts of electricity at his fingertips and placed them on her chest. 

A heartbeat? 

No.

“Please, Jiro…” He sobbed. “Wake up…” Again, he tried. Again, nothing. 

Tears leaked down his face. 

“Jiro…Don’t go, don’t leave me,” Kaminari lightly shook her, praying for some miracle, that she would suddenly wake up and laugh at him for crying. He looked at her face, flecked with beads of blood.

Her face remained frozen, her eyes closed in one last look of acceptance. Peace, even.

And Kaminari was far from that.

“She…she told me to run and hide,” Hagakure was shaking with fits of crying, drawing breaths between sobs. The hospital bed was shuddering dangerously with her. 

“I saw her run back. She used her jacks to create a tremor. It drew its attention, and then…” Her words dissolved into tears

“You left her,” Kaminari stated coldly. Hagakure cried some more at that, but he didn’t care. “You. Left –” 

“Kaminari! That’s enough!” Yaoyoruzu silenced him. She too was struggling to hold back her tears. “It wasn’t her fault. She couldn’t have done anything.”

“YES SHE COULD!” Kaminari roared, causing those around him to take a step back. “A MILLION THINGS, AND SHE WOULD STILL BE HERE!”

“Kaminari,” Kirishima interrupted, putting a hand on him. “Outside.”

The blonde shook it off roughly and stalked towards the exit, hands in his jacket. 

“Everyone’s grieving, the same as you. Don’t take it out on Hagakure,” Kirishima said, with constrained calmness. 

Kaminari growled and pounded his hand against the wall. He started to cry again. “I just…I…”

“I know, man. We all know.”

No you don’t, Kaminari thought, as he sunk lower and lower to the floor. It’s all my fault.

The jail was quiet. In a cell was the imprisoned death row convict, his jaws fitted with titanium. Security cameras watched him, and two guards kept watch on the dangerous criminal. 

The guard watching the cameras, a block away, yawned. His shift was almost over. Just one more hour… 

Static. Inexplicably, the camera feed died, causing the guard to immediately pick up the phone “Detail 1, do you copy? My feed just went to static.” 

No response. His eyes widened. He picked up another phone. “Squadron 3, emergency situation in block 3. Requesting backup.”

In block 3, two guards lay on the ground, shuddering violently as their bodies received a sudden 50 volts. 

Moonfish stirred awake from his sleep at the sound of yells cut short, and the smell of ozone. “Who’s…there?”

“You don’t know me.” Kaminari approached him from the darkness till Moonfish could see the teenager. “But I do.”

“Child. You were…on the list. I know you…”  

“Good,” Kaminari snarled. “It makes killing you so much more satisfying.” He held up his hand, and a bolt of electricity formed between his fingertips. 

“No…please…” Moonfish raised his head, but Kaminari reacted faster, swerving to the side, dodging the blade that sprouted from his incisor, out of reach of the titanium bars. Thrusting his hand out, he grabbed the blade and channelled his electricity into it. 

Shrieks of pain emitted from the convict. His head fell limp. Kaminari ignored the blood from his cut. 

“A death row convict, huh?” Kaminari stepped closer to Moonfish, till he could smell the putrid stench of corpses and blood on the criminal’s suit. 

“Consider this your sentence carried out.” 

“Command, block 3 is cleared. Detail 1 is safe. Sending them for checkup.”

“And the prisoner?”

“The prisoner’s dead.”

“Dead? How?”

“Well, apart from its head, everything else is ash. Burning ash.”

“Bloody hell…”

“We might have a lead on the intruder. We’ve picked up traces of blood.”

“Good. Send it to us. We’re gonna catch this bastard.”

“…Sir?”

“Yes?”

“Don’t you think the prisoner deserved it? He killed a kid.”

“Damn right he deserved it. When we catch whoever murdered the prisoner, I’d send them my thanks before they end up in the slammer.”

blog.name: mha-olympian
blog.title: Olympian
blog.description: Combining the thrilling world of sports with the incredible characters from My Hero Academia!

title: Happy New Years!~
body:
We haven’t checked in with you all in a while - how are you?

Life happened and hit the mods especially hard these past few months as this zine was in production, so we aren’t running on the schedule we had originally hoped we would. But worry not, this zine is still happening and we are opening pre-orders next week!

That being said, we have received questions about the official name of this zine and we wanted to tell you all when we released pre-orders!

The official name of this zine is Olympian!

This is Nai’s and my first zine, so please understand we were learning as we went. We apologize that its taken us this long to say anything, but we wanted to make sure that we had everything ready and prepped before we gave an update. So, this is that update! We’re doing some finishing touches on our store, and then we’re opening pre-orders! We’ll be doing a big post with the pre-order link when the store is officially open, so do not worry.

For this volume of Olympian (stay tuned on more information about future volumes), we will be selling a PDF Booklet AND a hard cover zine! All of our proceeds will be going to the Special Olympics, after production costs are paid for. The Special Olympics is a fantastic organization, and we’re so proud to be donating to them!

“The mission of Special Olympics is to provide year-round sports training and athletic competition in a variety of Olympic-type sports for children and adults with intellectual disabilities, giving them continuing opportunities to develop physical fitness, demonstrate courage, experience joy and participate in a sharing of gifts, skills and friendship with their families, other Special Olympics athletes and the community.” - Special Olympics

So, what the heck is happening next week? You can expect an updated artist list, previews of art that will be featured in this zine, and the pre-order link to order a PDF Booklet and Hard Cover Copy!

Thank you all for being so patient with us. We have learned so much, and we will be continuing to learn as we now enter pre-orders. We ask for you to please continue to be patient with us, and ask us questions at any time. Thank you again, we’re so excited to present Olympian!

Since this is a non-profit zine, our artists will be receiving a free hard copy and PDF booklet instead of any formal payment. We know that people care that artists are properly compensated for their work, so we wanted to assure everyone that our artists are being taken care of and are well loved.
